instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification models, and how well did this metric perform in identifying the moldy grades of maize kernels?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the classification models was the correct recognition rate (CRR). This metric performed well in identifying the moldy grades of maize kernels, as the model is considered to have strong recognition ability with indexes that are close to one.

instruction: How were the machine learning models utilized in the study to achieve the purpose of early detection of moldy maize kernels using hyperspectral imaging combined with sparse auto-encoders (SAE) and convolutional neural network (CNN) algorithms?
Output:
In the study, the machine learning models were utilized to classify the moldy grades of maize kernels based on hyperspectral imaging (HSI) combined with sparse auto-encoders (SAE) and convolutional neural network (CNN) algorithms. 

First, the HSI data in the range of 400-1000 nm were obtained to capture the spectral information of the maize kernels. 

The SAE algorithm was then used to represent the depth spectral features of the HSI data. This algorithm helps in learning a compact representation of the spectral features by reducing the dimensionality of the data. 

Next, the CNN algorithm was applied to extract image features from the HSI data. CNNs are effective in capturing spatial patterns and features from images. 

The spectral features obtained from SAE and the image features extracted by CNN were combined. 

Three different classifiers, namely K nearest neighbors, support vector machine (SVM), and partial least squares discriminant analysis, were used in combination with the spectral and image features to establish classification models. 

The fusion of SAE and CNN combined with the SVM classifier, known as the SAE-CNN-SVM model, yielded the most satisfactory identification results.

instruction: Can the fusion of sparse auto-encoders (SAE) and convolutional neural network (CNN) algorithms with the SVM classifier in the SAE-CNN-SVM model be considered a superior spectroscopic method for the early detection of moldy maize kernels using hyperspectral imaging?
Output: Yes, the fusion of sparse auto-encoders (SAE) and convolutional neural network (CNN) algorithms with the support vector machine (SVM) classifier in the SAE-CNN-SVM model can be considered a superior spectroscopic method for the early detection of moldy maize kernels using hyperspectral imaging. The comparison results indicated that this fusion model had the most satisfactory identification result with high correct recognition rates of 99.47% and 98.94% for the training and testing sets, respectively. Additionally, the values of sensitivity and specificity were 0.95-1, further demonstrating the effectiveness of this model. Therefore, the SAE-CNN-SVM model with hyperspectral imaging can provide good recognition ability for the early detection of moldy maize kernels, potentially supporting the development of online detection during storage.
